name: tsrts13
text: you've encountered a common problem amongst people attempting to scale mount everest via browser-based motercycle; namely that most internet images of mount everest leave little clearance room above the mountain for jumping.  were there a miniature internet-based human life actually in your browser riding a motorcycle he would likely clip the top of the mountain and fall to his death.  for shame.

name: tsrts13
text: and i spelled motorcycle wrong.  sweet.

name: pinballchacha
text: this = painfully true.

name: vandenbos
text: That's not your browser though, is it?  Looks to be an image viewer.

name: pinballchacha
text:
I don't think it's sad at all! It must take a Herculean amount of self-control *not* to hop straight off to Google Image Search after seeing this strip. And to spend the next half hour or so going VRRRRRM VRRRRRRRM and making like Evel Kinevel even tho I'm only on a laptop and the tiny touchpad kept causing me to crash into the summit so then I got some little pictures of Sir Edmund Hillary and Sherpa Tensing and started leading expeditions up there instead. But yeah, everybody has done this!!! Right? Everybody!!! In the world!!!!!!!!!1


oh god i have wasted my life.

Because it's just so right.

And because Onstad is so sparing about joking on pot, despite the fact that his audience is probably (my study has a sample size of one) less sparing about it's use.

name: hexjumper
text:
So, let me ask you this:

What's the best Achewood comic to get somebody interested in Achewood? I've got somebody in front of me, I want them to get curious about Achewood without spooking them with something that requires a lot of in-strip knowledge: What strip do I wanna use?

-Darren MacLennan

name: elzilcho
text:
Honestly? Start from the top. Others have said it before, but it bears repeating: there is just no way to see that first comic and NOT want to keep reading.

Maybe add in a disclaimer that it changes a lot from the beginning, maybe don't. But there's no one comic to show to a person. There will almost necessarily be a large amount of backstory and character development that bears explanation, and there's just no way to get that without trawling through the archives.

name: featurelessvoid
text: EBay Platinum Reserve may be a good place to start.  It's highly rated, it's funny without prior knowledge of the strip, and it blends back into an arc (the transfer station) that shows some of the main characters acting very much in-character.

name: evilpaul
text: GOF

name: phthoggos
text: Cartilage Head got me in.

name: sevendaughters
text: My way in was Badass Games. That's when I started reading, once it was over, I went straight to the top and read through.

name: pinballchacha
text: Can I put a word in for the flowcharts? I'd seen the occasional strip before, but it took a flowchart or two to make it all "click" for me, for some reason. Ebay Platinum Reserve/Philippe and the Couch and the Badass Games = seconded, too. But Cartilage Head is for goths. ;)

name: pinballchacha
text: (suddenly realises that the question is from four months ago. oh well.)

name: mendenbar
text: I don't know about you people, but for me I give a 5 if the comic makes me feel something really special. A true emotional response (like an artistic reflex), be it humor or something else. This comic always gives me a strong emotional response so everytime I see it Ill give it a 5. Its on the best, it deserves I really high rating. Thats what I think. I mean this particular comic would get a 5 just from the nostalgia  of the remembering the first time I read this: all laughing in history class, people staring at me, me having to leave the room... This strip is dank shit.

name: rickvigorous
text: A comment left by rickvigorous was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by evilpaul, jerkface, DESTROY_YOU, thesyndicate88)

name: quantumcasaba
text:
I am so disheartened when I see people getting hell for having an opinion that deviates from the norm.
Damn, man. I only know two other people outside of the internet that enjoy this comic and that's led me to believe that, while highly credited, it doesn't exactly appeal to the widest and most general demographic.
Unfortunately, time and time again I see that the same sort of "stick with us, say what we want/expect, and you will be respected" bullshit occurs.
It's not as though rick were being an asshole about it.

Bah, I'm thinking too much. And anyway, the fact that I even got involved enough to voice an opinion makes me no better.
God damn technology.

name: robobogle
text: You guys didn't have to rate it...

name: wittyname
text:
Though I agree with quantumcasaba, I didn't vote because I don't think a reissue makes the comic any better, but I didn't want to ruin everyones fun. I rated the original one a five. It's like an awesome meal: you eat it, it was good. But that doesn't mean it's going to be amazing when you end up seeing it later.

Does that analogy make sense? I think it made sense.

It might not have made sense.

name: quantumcasaba
text: I get you. Heh, I'm just hoping I didn't start strife with the internet. No offense was intended.

name: thesyndicate88
text: Did...did you just compare this comic to shit? I'll agree it's not the best ever, but that's just rough bro.

Man I hope it was never about that. I mean personally I just saw a 5 rating and said "hmm, let's see how long we can keep this thing goin'."

It was mostly funny because it is silly to vote 5 on a reissued strip.

Getting flak for voicing your opinion is pretty lame.
